prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As we mentioned in Science Case, all target sources are CH2NH sources. Since CH2NH is a precursor molecule to CH3NH2, the abundance of CH2NH would be a good indicator to estimate CH3NH2 abundance. Garrod (2013) conducted a chemical model calculation, and peak abundance of various COMs including CH2NH, CH3NH2, and glycine itself, are reported assuming different heating up speed of the core. The ratio of fractional abundances, “X[CH2NH]/X[CH3NH2]”, is roughly between 0.1 and 10, depending on the heating up speed. Halfen et al.(2013) reported that the column densities of CH2NH and CH3NH2 toward Sgr B2 are respectively 9.1x10^{14} and 5.0x10^{15} cm^{-2}, whose ratio is reproduced in the chemical model. Although actual observations imply CH3NH2 might be more abundant than that of CH2NH, this ratio may vary depending on the ISM environment, as shown in the Garrod (2013). Thus, we moderately estimate N(CH3NH2)=0.5xN(CH2NH).
Assuming the 5" source size, we estimated the column density of CH2NH in NGC6334F to be 2.3x10^{15} cm^{-2}. Assuming this value, some strong lines are found around 240-260 GHz region, under the relatively wide excitation temperature (30-110 K). We chose six transitions and the weakest line would be 0.03K toward NGC6334F. Since typical line width is 4km/s in NGC6334F, we will set the spectral resolution to be 141.113 kHz, corresponding to 0.162 km/s, to sufficiently resolve the lines. The spatial resolution is 2". Although the source size of organic molecule tend to be small, this beam size of ALMA will be filled with the CH3NH2 source. The required sensitivity to achieve 3-sigma detection of the weakest line in NGC6334F is 58 minutes (23 minutes on-source).

As we mentioned in Science Case, all target sources are CH2NH sources. Since CH2NH is a precursor molecule to CH3NH2, the abundance of CH2NH would be a good indicator to estimate CH3NH2 abundance. Garrod (2013) conducted a chemical model calculation, and peak abundance of various COMs including CH2NH, CH3NH2, and glycine itself, are reported assuming different heating up speed of the core. The ratio of fractional abundances, “X[CH2NH]/X[CH3NH2]”, is roughly between 0.1 and 10, depending on the heating up speed. Halfen et al.(2013) reported that the column densities of CH2NH and CH3NH2 toward Sgr B2 are respectively 9.1x10^{14} and 5.0x10^{15} cm^{-2}, whose ratio is reproduced in the chemical model. Although actual observations imply CH3NH2 might be more abundant than that of CH2NH, this ratio may vary depending on the ISM environment, as shown in the Garrod (2013). Thus, we moderately estimate N(CH3NH2)=0.5xN(CH2NH).
Assuming the 5" source size, we estimated the column density of CH2NH in G10.47+0.03 to be 1.0x10^{16} cm^{-2}. Assuming this value, some strong lines are found around 240-260 GHz region, under the relatively wide excitation temperature (30-110 K). We chose six transitions and the weakest line would be 0.56K toward G10.47+0.03. Since typical line width is 8km/s in G10.47+0.03, we will set the spectral resolution to be 282.227 kHz, corresponding to0.324km/s, to sufficiently resolve the lines. The spatial resolution is 2". Although the source size of organic molecule tend to be small, this beam size of ALMA will be filled with the CH3NH2 source. The required sensitivity to achieve 3-sigma detection of the weakest line inG10.47+0.03 is 31 minutes (2 minutes on-source).

As we mentioned in Science Case, all target sources are CH2NH sources. Since CH2NH is a precursor molecule to CH3NH2, the abundance of CH2NH would be a good indicator to estimate CH3NH2 abundance. Garrod (2013) conducted a chemical model calculation, and peak abundance of various COMs including CH2NH, CH3NH2, and glycine itself, are reported assuming different heating up speed of the core. The ratio of fractional abundances, “X[CH2NH]/X[CH3NH2]”, is roughly between 0.1 and 10, depending on the heating up speed. Halfen et al.(2013) reported that the column densities of CH2NH and CH3NH2 toward Sgr B2 are respectively 9.1x10^{14} and 5.0x10^{15} cm^{-2}, whose ratio is reproduced in the chemical model. Although actual observations imply CH3NH2 might be more abundant than that of CH2NH, this ratio may vary depending on the ISM environment, as shown in the Garrod (2013). Thus, we moderately estimate N(CH3NH2)=0.5xN(CH2NH).
Assuming the 5" source size, we estimated the column density of CH2NH in G31.41+0.3 to be 6.7x10^{15} cm^{-2}. Assuming this value, some strong lines are found around 240-260 GHz region, under the relatively wide excitation temperature (30-110 K). We chose six transitions and the weakest line would be 0.25K toward G31.41+0.3. Since typical line width is 6km/s in G31.41+0.3, we will set the spectral resolution to be 282.227 kHz, corresponding to 0.324km/s, to sufficiently resolve the lines. The spatial resolution is 2". Although the source size of organic molecule tend to be small, this beam size of ALMA will be filled with the CH3NH2 source. The required sensitivity to achieve 3-sigma detection of the weakest line in G31.41+0.3 is 34 minutes (5 minutes on-source).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Glycine precursors are key molecules in understanding chemical evolution of N-bearing molecules in the Universe and for future surveys of amino acids including glycine. However, precursor molecules and their formation paths are poorly investigated. We propose a survey of one possible glycine precursors, methylamine (CH3NH2) to not only to better understand poorly known chemistry of N-bearing complex organic molecules, but also to search for potential sources for future glycine survey. Prior to our proposed observations, we studied precursor molecule to CH3NH2, CH2NH, and discovered its new abundant sources: G31.41+0.3, G10.47+0.03, and NGC6334F. When our proposed observations are successful, we can demonstrate that CH3NH2-rich sources are potentially glycine-rich sources.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Data Center, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Data Center, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Mizusawa VERA Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
